comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The Dutch call those wooden shoes "Klompen," a word which I suspect is an example of onomatopoeia.

comment.author: 39839593@N00
comment._content:
Possibly, the word "klomp" is related to the English "clump", both meaning a heap or formless mass. The Dutch dictionary claims that the wooden shoe "klomp" is derived from the formless-mass meaning because the shoe is made from a clump of wood.

It is still worn today, usually in the rural parts of the Netherlands.

comment.author: 8291917@N07
comment._content: Photo was taken in the harbour of Volendam (my hometown). The man and girl are dressed in the local costume. The big white boat on the right is intriguing me: it is very 'untypical' for this harbour.
